values: Items crafted with this add fire damage
Items crafted with this add frost damage
Items crafted with this add lightning damage
Black adamantine ingot, heavy as sin and harder than anything known. This material refuses to yield, laughs at damage, and never breaks. Forged in earth's deepest fires.
Black ebony planks that absorb light. The wood feels cold, slightly wrong. Mages favor it for staves - it dampens unwanted magical interference while channeling intended power.
Bronze alloy forged from copper and tin. Stronger than either parent metal, the ancient alloy that built civilizations. The first lesson in combining materials.
Dense steel ingot, dark grey with a bluish tint. Carbon-rich iron forged under intense heat. Holds an edge far better than common iron, the mark of quality craftsmanship.
Fire-infused steel that burns without being consumed. The metal radiates heat, never cools. Weapons forged from this never need sharpening - they cauterize as they cut.
Flexible ash planks with excellent shock absorption. Bowyers and spearmakers favor this wood - it bends without breaking, springs back without warping. The wood of warriors.
Frost-forged steel, cold to the touch always. Ice crystals form on its surface in warm air. Blades made from this never rust, armor never overheats in battle.
Golden-green orichalcum ingot humming with elemental forces. Fire, ice, lightning course through its crystalline structure. The gods' preferred metal when they walked among mortals.
Ironwood planks, dense and metallic. Dulls saw blades quickly but the result is worth it - wood as strong as iron, light as oak. Nature's answer to steel.
Legendary mithril ingot, silvery-blue and impossibly light. The metal seems to defy natural laws - feather-light yet stronger than steel. Legends claim it fell from the stars.
Lightning-infused copper with perfect magical conductivity. Static crackles across its surface. The metal every mage dreams of - channels elemental power without resistance.
Refined copper ingot, reddish and malleable. The foundation of metallurgy - every smith's first metal. Soft enough to work easily, strong enough to be useful.
Silvery tin ingot with a subtle sheen. Rarely used alone, but essential for creating bronze alloys. The metal that teaches smiths about the power of combination.
Sturdy iron ingot, grey and reliable. The workhorse of civilization - strong enough for weapons, durable enough for tools, abundant enough to be practical.
Sturdy oak planks, well-seasoned and straight-grained. The standard for all woodworking - reliable, abundant, and easy to work with. Handles bear this wood with pride.
Worldtree planks that remember being part of something greater. The wood hums with ancient power. Items crafted from this are said to carry the world's will.

metadata.narrative: Dense steel ingot, dark grey with a bluish tint. Carbon-rich iron forged under intense heat. Holds an edge far better than common iron, the mark of quality craftsmanship.
